Situation1: They prepare a structured session to teach important skills before a project deadline.
Situation2: They notice a few pool chairs are slightly misaligned but still usable.
Story: I arrived early, determined to make the most of my mentoring session. My mentees were counting on me to guide them through the final steps before their big project deadline. I’d spent hours preparing a structured lesson, eager to share the skills they needed. As I set up in the poolside lounge, my lifeguard instincts kicked in. I noticed a few pool chairs were out of line—nothing dangerous, but not up to the standard I was expected to maintain. The facility manager had been clear: everything should be orderly, always. I glanced at my watch. The mentees would arrive any minute, expecting my full attention and expertise. But the misaligned chairs nagged at me, a silent reminder of my responsibility as a lifeguard. Should I pause to fix them, risking a rushed or distracted session? Or ignore them for now, knowing I’d be falling short of my other duty? The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
